question_content.barrons:question: Select a sentence in the second paragraph whose function is to raise a possibility.

barrons:choices.barrons:choice: At first sight this would appear to be an early example of the type of scientific procedure proposed by Descartes in 1637 for eliminating all but one of a number of possible relationships.

In the ideal type of “critical” experiment, however, each “possibility” should be derived from existing data (or be a logical extrapolation of it) and the whole should be structured so that alternative possible explanations are excluded.
Failure to satisfy these requirements reduces an experiment to a level of controlled empiricism.

This was the weakness of Lind’s work: the six “possible” cures that he compared were presumably selected empirically from those currently favored by ships’ surgeons; he gives no indication that his choice was governed by any other consideration.
His experiment “succeeded” simply because one of the “remedies” contained vitamin C (the anti-scorbutic factor) whereas the other five did not.
